10   Appendix 3 
PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
1.  The  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  is  required  to  undertake  due 
diligence to (i) assess improvements required to urban services in select municipalities in the 
Far Western Region of Nepal (FWRN), and (ii) identify strategic actions to guide the region’s 
urban development and build capacity for operations and maintenance.  
 
2.  The TA will develop the project scope, which includes identifying priorities, subproject 
screening, pre-feasibility, and conceptual design. The TA will be structured into two phases. 
 
Phase 1 includes: 
 
(i)  development  of  a  strategic  regional  and  urban  assessment,  and  Bhimdatta-
Attariya-Dhangadhi corridor development strategy; 
(ii)  development of a strategic infrastructure investment plan; 
(iii)  development of the project scope; 
(iv)  rapid assessments for safeguards compliance; 
(v)  socio-economic analysis based on household socio-economic survey and focus 
group discussions; 
(vi)  institutional  and  financial  capacity  assessment  of  the  executing  agency, 
implementing agency, and project municipalities; 
(vii)  designing the implementation arrangements; 
(viii)  defining the scope of work for the design and supervision consultant (DSC); and 
(ix)  assisting the executing agency in recruiting the DSC. 
 
Phase 2 includes: 
 
(i)  overseeing the DSC’s outputs, and 
(ii)  supporting the executing agency in preparing loan documents.1  
 
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
 
3.  The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table A3.1. The DSC appointed 
through advance actions will undertake further detailing of the interventions identified by the TA 
and develop detailed engineering designs and cost estimates, safeguards plans, and bidding 
documents. 
 
Table A3.1: Summary of Major Outputs and Activities 
Major Activities  ECD  Major Outputs  ECD 
PPTA consultant mobilization  January 2015  DSC RFP issued by GON  May 2015 
Undertake safeguards screening  March 2015  Socio-economic report  June 2015 
Undertake technical assessment  April 2015  Pre-feasibility report for project  June 2015 
DSC EOI issued by GON  March 2015  Financial management assessment  January 2016 
GON evaluates DSC proposals  July 2015  DSC contract award  January 2016 
DSC = design and supervision consultants, ECD = expected completion date, EOI = expression of interest, GON = 
Government of Nepal, PPTA = project preparatory technical assistance, RFP = request for proposal. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
                                                
1 This does not include loan agreements.

C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
 
4.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 equivalent which will be financed on a grant basis 
by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Funds  (TASF-V).  The  government  will  provide 
counterpart support in the form of  counterpart staff, office accommodation, communication 
facilities for consultants, and other in-kind contributions. The detailed cost estimate is presented 
in Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
 
5.  Seven  individuals  comprising  4  international  consultants  and  3  national  consultants 
(providing  30  person-months  of  input)  will  be  engaged  by  ADB  to  undertake  the  TA  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time). The contingency may be used to increase specific experts’ inputs as required during the 
TA. Table A3.3 summarizes the consulting services requirement for the individuals.

12  Appendix 3 
 
6.  The outline terms of reference for the TA consultants are described in paragraphs 7 to 
12. 
 
  1.  Outline terms of reference for international consultants 
 
7.  Team Leader and Urban Infrastructure Specialist (7 person-months). The Team 
Leader  is  preferred  to  be  a  Civil  Engineer  or  Urban  Planner  with  minimum  20  years  of 
experience in the infrastructure and urban planning industry with a focus on urban services. 
She/he will (i) work with the Regional/Urban Planner to define the project scope; (ii) coordinate 
the  technical  feasibility  assessment,  safeguards  assessment,  procurement  capacity 
assessment,  and  project  structuring;  (iii)  assist  on  bidding  document  preparation  and  bid 
process management for identified advance procurement actions for the DSC; (iv) oversee the 
DSC’s outputs, and (v) draft the RRP and PAM for loan appraisal. All team members will report 
to the Team Leader.  
 
8.  Municipal  Finance  Expert  (4  person-months).  The  Municipal  Finance  Expert  is 
preferred to have an extensive knowledge of working with service utilities in South Asia – power, 
telecom or water - for a minimum of 15 years. She/he should preferably be an Accountant. 
She/he will (i) undertake a governance and financial assessment of project municipalities and 
executing and implementing agencies; (ii) develop an action plan and identify support measures 
for  each  municipality  to  increase  its  own  source  revenue;  (iii)  design  funds  flow  and 
disbursement mechanisms for the ensuing project; (iv) identify capacity building measures on 
financial management; (v) prepare a financial model to simulate cash flows for urban services; 
and (vi) suggest a tariff structure for urban services based on the modeling. She/he will identify 
the scope of work related to economic and financial analysis for the DSC and review the 
economic and financial analysis prepared by the DSC. 
 
9.  Environmental  and  Social  Safeguards  Expert  (4  person-months).  The 
Environmental and Social Safeguards Expert is preferred to have at least 15 years of relevant 
experience working on safeguards in the infrastructure industry, preferably with experience on 
ADB projects. She/he will (i) undertake rapid safeguards screening and identify adverse impacts 
associated  with  proposed  subprojects,  (ii)  develop  an  environmental  assessment  review 
framework,  (iii)  develop  a  resettlement  framework,  (iv)  identify  scope  of  work  related  to 
safeguards for the DSC, and (v) review the DSC’s safeguards related outputs prepared for loan 
appraisal. She/he should preferably have working knowledge of national environmental and land 
acquisition and resettlement related laws and regulations to effectively reconcile sovereign 
policies with the ADB Safeguards Policy Statement. 
 
10.  Sr.  Social  Development  and  Gender  Expert  (3  person-months).  The  Social 
Development Expert is preferred to have experience undertaking poverty reduction and social 
impact assessments, and gender-related work for a minimum of 5 years in Nepal. The Specialist 
will design a household survey and oversee the survey and focus group discussions. She/he will 
produce a socio-economic report for the project municipalities based on the data collection 
(including analysis related to demographics, access to infrastructure and municipal services, 
and vulnerability issues). She/he will identify ongoing work of civil society organizations in the 
project municipalities. She/he will also develop the scope of work for the DSC related to social 
development and access to services and preparation of the gender action plan for the project.

Appendix 3  13 
  2.  Outline terms of reference for national consultants 
 
11.  Regional/Urban Planning Expert (4 person-months). The Regional Planning Expert is 
preferred to be a planner or economist with minimum 10 years of experience in the planning and 
infrastructure industry. She/he will (i) develop an urban strategy and development framework for 
the FWRN, with a focus on the Bhimdatta-Attariya-Dhangadhi corridor; and (ii) recommend 
implementation arrangements for the project based on institutional capacity for implementation, 
planning, and operations and maintenance. The implementation arrangements should be based 
on (a) lessons learned; (b) the legal, regulatory and institutional framework for the sector, as 
applicable; and (c) government structures at both the district and municipal levels. She/he will 
provide support in identification of regional infrastructure, if any, and supporting the consultation 
process with municipalities and the central government. She/he will also identify the scope of 
work related to urban and regional planning for the DSC. 
 
12.  Civil Engineer (4 person-months). The Civil Engineer is preferred to have a minimum 
of 10 years of experience. He/she will provide support to the Team Leader and the Safeguards 
Expert. He/she will help to (a) identify priority urban infrastructure investments and (b) undertake 
an initial technical assessment of the identified subprojects and develop conceptual designs. 
He/she will also identify technical capacity improvements required in project municipalities to 
operate and maintain infrastructure. The Civil Engineer will also support the government in the 
bid evaluation process.  
 
13.  Finance Expert (4 person-months). The Finance Expert shall have a minimum of 10 
years of relevant work experience in Nepal. He/she will work closely with and support the 
international Municipal Finance Expert to assess the project municipalities’ financial capacity. 
He/she will collect necessary data and provide overall support for consultations, modeling and 
assessments.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  The MOUD will be the TA’s executing agency. It will provide in-kind contributions in the 
form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, office supplies, and communication facilities for 
consultants. The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A3.4. 
Consultants will be mobilized in a staggered manner with a focus on prioritizing the (i) socio-
economic household survey, and (ii) recruitment of the DSC. Disbursement under the TA will be 
in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (May  2010,  as 
amended). 
 
Table A3.4: Technical Assistance Processing and Implementation Schedule 
Major Milestones  Expected Completion Date 
Project concept paper clearance  Dec 2014 
Consultant mobilization  Feb 2015 
Socio-economic surveys completed  April 2015 
TA completion date  March 2017 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates
